The web has changed but there remain remnants of what it once was in terms of personal sites. I track some of those remnants, curating such sites (which are still active, or when Iâ€™m lucky, new), hoping to somehow keep my original vision of the web intact. Iâ€™ve got scars that canâ€™t be seen.content: I want to deal with whatâ€™s possible, not wallow is whatâ€™s already taken place and left its ugly mark.

I can remember walking around the old neighborhood wondering what water temperature would be best for washing my hair. I also thought about whether or not I would ever have it cut again. It had grown quite long while I was in school and coming back to the neighborhood after almost four years was awkward for me to say the least. I needed to find a job quick. Living in that old house again on Royal Palm Avenue with my mother wasn't an option. I wouldn't have been able to handle that for very long and as it turned out, I didn't have to. Nor did I cut my hair.

By the time I got to New York.content: From Colorado to Delaware to Florida to Illinois to Michigan. All the stops in oneâ€™s journey define who they are and going back to where one started is just a visit to another new, though familiar place.

I can remember walking around the old neighborhood wondering what water temperature would be best for washing my hair. I also thought about whether or not I would ever have it cut again. It had grown quite long while I was in school and coming back to the neighborhood after almost four years was awkward for me to say the least. I needed to find a job quick. Living in that old house again on Royal Palm Avenue with my mother wasn't an option. I wouldn't have been able to handle that for very long and as it turned out, I didn't have to. Nor did I cut my hair.

We lived above the sub shop. My parents had opened one of areaâ€™s first, specializing in [Italian subs](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#sub), Philly steak sandwiches, Sicilian pizza, and other goodies. Itâ€™s not surprising I was a fat little kid back then.

It was an old step van and the passenger seat wasnâ€™t anchored. As my father drove, the seat slid forward then back then forward again. What a ride! Iâ€™m [guessing](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#shatters) I was about 10 or 11-years-old then based on the fact that Tony was with us in the van. He was a guy my father helped to immigrate from Cuba (in 1959?). We were on the way to [the bay](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#the%20bay).

Decades ago, I was one of the giggling twins standing and jumping up and down on the passenger seat next to our mother who was driving the little Nash Rambler. I think we were about 3 years old at the time and this is the earliest memory Iâ€™ve managed to retain over the years.
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.
getting lost on the web is all i live for now getting lost on the web is my fate getting lost on the web is a sign itâ€™s too late
Thereâ€™s a number of other pleasant memories since then through the next 5 years or so but many moments in my youth thereafter were destined to become repressed memories as an adult.
you are me before the storm
getting lost is the real deal
40 years later, looking back, I realize that little has changed.
